To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

If you see the movie “Big Miracle,” you’ll notice a couple of Minnesota guys depicted onscreen. Thankfully, their names have been changed to protect the nongoofballs.

Greg Ferrian of Mendota Heights becomes “Karl Hootkin,” who travels to Alaska to help an international effort to free three whales trapped in the ice. James LeGros plays Hootkin with an accent and degree of goofiness that make the characters in “Fargo” look like they’re in a documentary. That, and liberties Ferrian feared would be taken with the story he participated in, had him nervous about seeing the movie. To his surprise, he’s a big fan of “Big Miracle.”

“Honestly, I think it’s going to be a hit,” said Ferrian, a manufacturer’s representative in microelectronics. “I think people my age (55) will want to see it and my grandkids will want to see it.”

“Big Miracle” is based on “Freeing the Whales,” a book that describes events in October 1988, when the plight of a trio of California gray whales dubbed Fred, Wilma and Pebbles became a global phenomenon. Ferrian heard about it the way everyone did: on the news.

“I came home from work, and I was watching TV while I was changing my clothes. It happened to be a slow day on the news, and I saw this story about the whales,” Ferrian said. “A light bulb went off immediately that I had a solution.”

The solution was the Kasco De-icer, called the Hootkin De-icer in the film. Invented by Ferrian’s father-in-law, Bill Skluzacek, it was introduced in the early 1970s to keep boats and docks free of ice. Instantly, Ferrian was convinced the de-icer was the solution to freeing the whales, and within 15 minutes and a couple of phone calls, he was speaking to one of the key figures on the ice in remote Barrow, Alaska, where the drama was taking place.

“The whole thing is amazing to me,” Ferrian said. “It still doesn’t make sense how it all happened – back in those days, not having cellphones and all.”

Although, if cellphones had been in common usage, Ferrian probably wouldn’t have found himself on that same Barrow ice within days. Skluzacek was at a convention on the East Coast and unreachable by phone. Decision-makers in Alaska were available by phone but were not convinced the Kasco de-icer, basically a fan that churns around water to keep slush and ice from forming, would do the job. So Ferrian did what he had to do. He lied.

“We raided the family bank account for $3,500 bucks. And I told my brother-in-law, Rick, they wanted us up there – it was kind of a white lie – and he and I headed up,” Ferrian said.

Once Ferrian and Rick Skluzacek, 51, of Cottage Grove arrived in Alaska, it still took a lot of convincing. But as the movie shows, within hours of putting the de-icer to use, the slush was cleared and the whales had room to breathe. Kasco’s $3,500 was never reimbursed, but the company ended up getting lots of free advertising.

Many details in the film are fictionalized. For instance, “Big Miracle” shows the characters based on Ferrian and Rick Skluzacek, who is wackily named “Dean Glowacki,” showing up well after reporters turned it into a worldwide story. They actually arrived early in the effort, staying for 10 days. And the job of helicoptering a generator to the whales’ ice hole wasn’t as perilous as it looks in the film. But on balance, Ferrian says he was pleasantly surprised by the movie when he saw it at a screening in Washington, D.C., last week.

“I went in with a negative attitude. My wife kept reminding me the story was ‘inspired by’ rather than the real story, but I couldn’t get to that point because I’d been there,” said Ferrian, who was interviewed by the filmmakers and visited the Alaska set in October 2010. “Then, afterward, I came out with a smile on my face. I needed to understand the Hollywood thought process, and that finally hit me somewhere toward the middle of the movie.”

He was still smiling when a stranger came up to him after the screening and said, as Ferrian recalled, ” ‘Before I introduce myself, I want you to promise not to hit me.’ He was the screenwriter who wrote Carl, the one based on me. He said he went to school in Madison and that after a few beers, he and his college buddies used to joke around and do the ‘Fargo’ accent, so he had to get it in the movie.”

Which explains what that ridiculous “Minnesota” accent is doing in “Big Miracle.” But Ferrian, who had no previous interest in whales and never considered himself much of an environmentalist, cannot account for what drew him to Fred, Wilma and Pebbles in the first place.

“I honestly have no clue. I’ve wondered about it,” Ferrian said. “But none of this makes sense other than there’s some kind of magic about whales.”
